content:
14, 2016
Teal DeerDevelopers: EA Redwood Shores Publishers: Electronic Arts Initial release: Oct 2008Genre: Action, Horror#Worth/NotWorth: #WorthExposition, Concurrence and SummationDead Space is a horror game. In where you play as our reluctant and intrepid hero Issac Clarke, a technician. Sent to the USG Ishimura, a Planet-Cracker class ship designed for mining. Upon arrival, Issac and friends have a bit of a tift actually docking with the Ishimura. After avoiding near death almost immediately upon introduction. We find ourselves upon the ship ready to get to work; Only no one is responding to our radio hails. Entrance into the first room, we are attacked by monsters later given the name Necromorphs and being the consummate professional that Issac is we decide to continue to repair the ship regardless of it's now infested alien presence. And so it begins...It's not a terribly in depth game. It is indeed your basic walk through hallways and shoot anything that moves sort of affair. But it's an effective and atmospheric one even still today. Is it contrived that in a world that requires you to dismember enemies you're given a plasma cutter that is effective at range and presumably your character would know not only how to use  it but an expert in his field? Yes, it is. The story is more in depth, I feel, than most horror. Creating a universe rather than “an experience”. Without saying anything specific, the game makes commentary on the frivolity of desperation in the creation of a new religion based almost exclusively on not knowing something. The game does feature what I'd consider “insanity effects” but they are more scripted than ambient. Throughout the game Issac does not speak. Sometimes awkwardly not saying anything but mostly this is reminiscent of the Gordon Freeman effect wherein it allows the player to place themselves more into the role. Now, at this point I should mention this is my 3rd play-through of this game and that I have also completed the rest of the trilogy. The series takes a direction that I am both happy with and thought could have been better. But that is neither here nor there. This is the beginning of that adventure. Mechanically, it's a shooter with a camera made popular by Gears of War and Resident Evil 4. It was also made in a time that “immersion” was all the rage. The HUD appears entirely “in-game” meaning that all feedback normally given to the player (Health, power for abilities, ammo count, inventory) are all made visible in-world to the characters themselves. You collect power nodes used for upgrading either your suit or weapons. The big mechanically unique thing regarding this game is the Zero-gravity areas. They are interesting, at the time they may have been more impressive but they stand to be a pretty standard element. Sound design is excellent, walking into the vacuum of space is always an incredible feeling hearing only the muffled shuffles within your own suit.Now, there is a section of this game that is borderline game breaking. It's one of the more egregiously needless frustrating sections of a game I've ever seen. Which incidentally speaks volumes to the rest of the game. I don't want to say exactly what it is, I get that it's supposed to be a stressful situation but I know a number of people that actually stopped playing the game because of that section. Addressing more topical issues, the game has full gamepad support and there is no issue with this. However, if you desire to use mouse and keyboard you'll notice that even at max sensitivity the controls are as though they are stuck in quickly hardening mud. (I used a 1600DPI mouse at max sensitivity and moved the mouse roughly 1ft actual space and turned about 90° in game) However, there is a simple solution to these issues. For whatever reason EA forgot to and didn't patch the fact the game V-sync doesn't include the mouse (console ports huh), so you'll have to force enable it through the video card control panel. The v-sync works as expected otherwise. THE GISTAtmospheric, weight-y and  heavy combat with a great narrative universe.Follow my curation for more

content:
ry 12
												In my opinion, Dead Space is one of the best horror/shooter games out there, with just the right amount of atmosphere and jump scares. It focuses on a unique dismemberment mechanic, and trying to cut off enemiess legs while they charge you is always a rush. This game is more the spiritual successor to System Shock than Bioshock, which uses an upgrade system that makes your choices matter. There isn't as many utility skills as System Shock, but which weapons you choose to level up with your very limited upgrade nodes changes your playstyle. Just a few flaws specific to the Steam version: mouse acceleration is terrible in this game and you can't disable it within the settings. There's a fix you can download from pcgamingwiki which makes it bearable again, but it still feels off, especially using the mouse in menus. Also, once the mouse is fixed, the precision aiming makes the game much easier than intended. I originally played this on the 360 and I recall it being much more difficult. Enemies that would take 4-5 shots now go down in 2 well-placed shots, which also makes ammo too abundant. Still, it's a great game that aged well in the nearly decade it's been out.

content:
5, 2016
												I bought the game as a bundle with the second one. I was hoping to play through them both but unfortunately for me and apparently for many others the controls on the PC port are completely broken, there is extreme input lag unless you turn v-sync off, the mouse sensitivity is excruciating low and has negative acceleration, meaning I literally couldnt turn a corner unless i picked up my mouse and moved it across the pad several times. Even with the fixes on the forums that require you alter the files for the game, I experienced freezes in the mouse controls, and glitches with the movement. Finally I hit an invisible wall in the only path forward, meaning I had to quit the game before even the first save point. I didn't bother to try to sit through the unskippable opening cutscene again.Luckily when i went ahead to the second game I found that none of these problems persisted and I was pleasantly surprised with extremely fluid controls and movement animations. I would only buy this game if you are looking to play through the whole series, because it is likely your game will be broken and you will have to jump through hoops to actually play it. If you are just looking for a bit of the dead space experience skip this one and go for number 2.

content:
y 20, 2014
												EDIT: I bought a Xbox 360 controller and this game works perfectly with it. While this is good news it still does not change the fact that this game sucks with KB/M. Also to anyone who disagrees with me, please post a comment telling me why.This review is for the PC version only. I love this game, and have played it all the way through around four times. In my opinion, this game has one of the best horror atmospheres ever. Although its almost all jump scares, it kept me on my toes the entire game. The story was good enough to keep me entertained, and the use of audio logs was amazing. Nothing really wrong with the base game, a perfect jump-horror game. My HUGE issue with the PC port is the horrid control issues. Even on max sensitivity, it would take entire seconds to turn the camera around, and only through notepad tweaking could I make it bearable. This "solution" would ultimately create a form of mouse acceleration, so the movement was still not smooth. V-Sync is horribly tied into this game, which I believe is what causes this issues. Please buy this amazing game, but on a console, and tell the developers to stop putting out unacceptable PC ports.Pros:+Loads fastNegatives:-Absolutely unplayableOverall: 1/10 Do NOT buy this version, but please get it on console. This is one of my favourite horror games ever made, and it truly saddens me to give it such a low score, but this port absolutely sucked.

content:
ber 10, 2016
												I'm not new to Dead Space. I got this game back when it came out for PS3 and it since then become one of my most loved franchises to have ever existed. Everything about this game was so perfect and back in the days, never seen in a game before. It mixed sci-fi with horror in such a way that movies like Alien and Predator could only do. Being the early 80's child that I am, this brought many smiles of joy, as well as screams of terror.I will not go much into detail, since most people who play this will be familiar with the game, wether they played it for Xbox or PS3. This game hasn't aged too well though. With so many masterpieces of the horror franchises out there, like Outlast and even the sci-fi brother Alien Isolation, Dead Space somehow does not feel too scary anymore. Not to say it's bad, but when you play Alien Isolation and then start Dead Space right after, you are not into it for the scares, but for the nostalgia.Nevertheless, Dead Space is a masterful game. So original that not many (or any) games could copy or surpass it, unless of course, we look at Dead Space 2. But I'm leaving that for another review.So moving on to the technical details:Graphics: -Playing this at 1080p on a GTX970 paired with an i5 6600k with 10% OC, running at 60fps with all settings maxed out. I can't say it looks great... It is 100x smoother than the PS3 version, yes, but that kind of hurts the game a bit since it makes the old and blurry textures stand out. The PS3 version was a lot darker, more grainy and the 30fps helped with the "cinematic" feel. Maybe it was my imagination. maybe back then this game looked great since there wasn't anything better.One th epossitive: Light effects are a lot sharper though, and the holographic menu looks gorgeous!Sound:-As wonderful and nerve-wrecking as I rememberControls:-Now this is where the game suffers terribly. This game on a keyboard and mouse is a no-go. Playing it with an Xbox One controller does help, but the analogs are way too sensitive compared to the absolute perfection that the Dual Shock 3 analogs were. I don't remember this game being this clunky (maybe it was), but now it is very bad. It will need some getting used to, but it will certainly won't stop me from enjoying.Story:-Very engaging, original, great character that you'll learn to love. It's like a good sci-fi B movie. It also takes some inspiration from the Alien franchise.Setting:-The sci-fi lore here is very good. I am an amature sci-fi novelist and it is absolute bliss to play this game for all those little science details. Even if some strech reality a bit, without getting too far from what it is possible.Replay value:-Not much to see here really. THis is a game you play once in a while.Port quality:-WARNING READ THIS: A lot of people complain of crashing, lag and glitchy v-sync. Be aware that this game does not play well on all systems. However there are a lot more people like me that are having absolutely NO problems with this game even maxed out. still, if you go for it and do experience problems, there are tons of threads here in the Steam community of fixes and setting combos that will certainly make the experience much more enjoyable.10/10 One of those great games that will forever be remembered in the gaming industry. Godly sequel, and even if the end of the trilogy wasn't too great (game-wise), it gave a spectacular finale to the hero that Isaac Clarke is.

content:
ber 27, 2016
												This is an amazing game. It has borrowed some of the mechanics from Bioshock, but it is nowhere near a "Bioshock in space". Where bioshock has offered you a wierd and twisted sense of dementia, this game offers a cold hard fictional reality of deep space. It is gritty, dirty and bloody in right amounts. It gives you that feeling of palpable reality that you can almost taste. If you are a fan of Event Horizon, Alien etc, you will love this game.The camera is over the shoulder 3rd person, which adds to the atmosphere of something lurking just behind your back and you not being able to clearly see it. One of the greatest additions, which I want to see in all games from now on is the complete integration of GUI into the game world. There is no button that takes you out of the game, everything you do, whether browsing your inventory or checking your map is done within the world. All readings like health, air etc are integrated into your suit so you have nothing that detaches you from the world. It is amazing how an apparently simple thing as that can add to the game atmosphere.Without giving too much away the game begins with you and a crew of astronauts on course to investigate a distress beacon from a stricken spaceship, and you guessed it all hell has broken loose when you arrive. You find yourself from the very beginning isolated from your crew forced to stumble your way through the eerie and downright terrifying tunnels and rooms of the stricken ship.And the atmosphere is scary, confined and claustrophobic. Parts where you go to 0G are downright disorienting in a right way, being that you are able to walk on ceilings and walls, you can easily lose the feeling of what is up and what is down.

content:
1, 2016
												Dead Space is a fun horror survival game I have owned numours times and enjoyed replaying. I first bought this game on the PS3 and put almost 2 days worth into playing it both for achievements and the experience. Dead Space's atmosphere is great and does a beautiful job of creating a spooky sci-fi horror on top of third person survival shooting. The game's story starts off as players playing as an engineer named Isac Clark who knows how to fix  EVERYTHING  and his team who were sent to fix a planet cracker ship called the Ishimurra. Clark's wife named Nicole was working on the Ishimurra untill something went wrong with their dig site and sent out a distress call for help. As Clark's team enters the Ishimurra they uncover the horrorfying necromorphs in the ship and try to desperatly escape. This game offers hours of fun from straight replayability to the experimenting with gear and tactics used to help you survive. The equipment in Dead Space is upgradable consisting of your suit (RIG), Stasis, Kenisis Module, and a total of 6 guns to use; 5 of them purchasable in game. These upgrades require nodes found in game or purchased at the store to upgrade their arsenal. In order to kill these necromorphs players are forced to shoot/cut thier limbs off instead of just shooting their head or torso bringing a new formula to survival shooting. Shooting thier legs off will only make them crawl towards players and shooting their heads off will make them swing wildly and aimlessly. The horror in this game is good and provides good jump scares even to people who replay the game. There are small mini games in Dead Space both rewarding prizes that aid the player in upgrading equipment or selling to the store. Dead Space is a great horror survival shooter with replayability both for higher difficulty and new game + to experiment with new weapons or simply play again with current equipment. I would not recommend purchasing this game on its own purchasing the Dead Space 1 & 2 bundle is a better price and more bang for your buck as the sequel is equally if not better than the original Dead Space.

content:
r 22, 2016
												Dead Space is probably one of the best scifi action-horror games I've played. It has amazing atmosphere, visuals that still hold up, art design and interface design that blends awesomely and some of the best sound design ever. Firstly, if you get this game turn the music off. Yes, off. It has musical ques that while cool, give away there are enemies around/alive. If there's still some kind of music playing, you have a monster about. It ruins the atmosphere as great as the music is. You get a number of weapons that have alternate firing modes that make the game pretty damn replayable. All function differently and offer different pluses and minuses. Some people write this off as jumpscare the game, I say ...well yeah kinda. But that's fine since the tension matches the jumpscare. Stand idle in any area and listen. The sounds you hear, the creaking of the ship, the buzzing of electronics and the rustling of monsters really sets the mood. This game is the scifi-version of Resident Evil. You're trapped in a large place and have to deal with the hell onboard while dealing with limited supplies. You'll be running all over the ship doing tasks but things change as you go along, it's never dull. They keep things interesting. The interface is as I said, brilliant. There's no hud. All of Issac's gauges are on the back of his suit, or project from them, including the menus. It's really really well thought out and it keeps you focused on what's important, the center of the screen. Now on to the problems. This is a old PC game indeed, right when PC games were getting back on track with decent ports. This game is pretty good but I'm going to say some things that may break this game for you. Unless you change the game to have vsync every time you enter it, the game will lock at 30 if booted with vsync on. If you put vsync on after the game is on it'll lock to 60. However blasphemous as it sounds, you may prefer 30FPS since if you leave the framerate unlocked the mouse controls even at wildly high sensitivity levels are too slow to use. Also, the physics go haywire at above 30, killed enemies will bounce up and zero G bodies will start spinning like tornadoes. The crap mouse controls can be countered by using ....I'm gonna say it, a controller. Works perfectly with a XB360 or XB1 controller straight away. Which may not be ideal but it works. There could be a mod to fix this as well, I'm not sure. But I've played it with a controller and it's nice. Then again I've used controllers a bunch back in the PS2 days so I'm familiar with them. The last thing I noticed is if you jump in zero G at too narrow an angle, the game can bug out. <-this is avoidable. Even with these problems I still recommend it. You may have to use a controller or use a mouse at 30fps but it's still a fun game. I kinda link it with you're not supposed to be a badass shot, you're supposed to unused to shooting people/creatures. The sequel fared much better in terms of porting and is also a great game.

content:
er 30, 2013
												Dead Space to me is like Super Mario 64 to my Nintendo machine.  I don't know how and why the Dead Space series has slipped over the years, but Dead Space 1 was always the best Dead Space and a genre defining game.  In fact, no one has really created a game where there are space zombies, you fight these things in space, combined with scare and horror with the dread of being alone.  You are truly alone in space.  Dead Space 2 was great too but no where as near as great as Dead Space.  It's one of those games that left an imprint in my recollection of gaming experiences along with Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of Time, Super Mario 64, Street Fighter, Goldeneye 64, Lost Odyssey, Valkyria Chronicles, Halo series, and a few others.  The Dead Space Universe is where the heart is.  There's vast potential.  The world of Dead Space is intriguing, and when well written, developed, and executed, it's the definitive space zombie game with a major twist.  But to call it space zombie is a hit from the hilt.  It's a lot more than that.  They're called necromorphs, and they're terrifying.  Horrific.  They terrorize your soul.The premise of Dead Space is overwhelming with potential possibilities that could bring the series back to life.  Dead Space 4, if it happens, will hopefully revisit the memories of the first game.  It's a must-play, sit in a dark room, with your headphones on video game.  Immerse yourself fully into its atmosphere and it will be one of the best times you've spent playing a game.Rating: 9.2 out of 10

content:
er 20, 2016
												I like Alien Isolation but I have no respect for the main director Alistair Hope, this guy obviously knows sh*t about it and his team probably did all his work on his place. He said that ''horror and the survival genre" were banalized by games like Dead Space (he meant the series) and the violence and action suffered with it. Well, tell me about banalization 21st Century Fox... Colonial Marines was your idea. I wish I could have said that publicly but better late than never, you and your publishers were just full of sh*t.Most games you play were later created after the engine firstly made to build it, ultimately leaving it with some limitations followed by many cuts of contents. ‎Wright Bagwell and Dead Space's main writters ‎Warren Ellis, Rick and Antony were the only guys at the time to have enough balls to go for the opposite direction creating the plot first then the engine later, based on the idea blowing the genre and changing industry's rules. Maybe that's why the scary jumpy moments still works to this date and why it feels so mature during every scene and event. Voice acting was/is absurdly good and it was probably the first game to take motion capture so seriously. Screams from the Necromorph are ridiculously well done. "There is no scape" feeling precedes that. Even if I dislike Dead Space 3 so much, the studio works can still be seen there. No, it shouldn't have been a first person, period. Ask about RE4 Shoulder Camera.It's incredible how those sci-fi machinery can look and feel dead serious to mess with. This constant feeling of ''I'm screw*d" persists with everything you do and walk on. Game came out by 2008 so expect some clunky mechanics and outdated graphics, old ideas like non-voiced main character (later improved and evolved) but those were features made to last and it sure does its job which I'm still impressed. If you think I'm exaggerating, only after a time I came to know about a mind blowing secret from the game. By now you may already know about the bathroom thing, but I will blur it all here because it wasn't just there... It's actually scattered all around USG Ishimura.During the entire game some brillant form of subliminal voice and textures were running on the background and later on I came to know about the creepy whispers. They were so low you couldn't really hear or make sense out of it.  Now... this explain why the game was always scary even when nothing was happening. ID Software was reluctant to use those techniques on Doom 3, they were affraid about some Disney-like accusations but Eastwood Studios didn't gave a sh*t. The symbols on walls aren't just symbols, they're an actual hidden language. The fictious group Unithology is clearly messing with the real world Scienthology religion bullsh*t. When you find this out you start to realize the game isn't about biological weapons and that the enemy might be more darker in nature and origin. Answers should come after DS3 but the Dead Moon looked hellish, but not really from ... hell?  Since Dead Space 3 got the plot so f*ck*d up, we may never known anymore. The series are now indefinitely cancelled. EA broke further partneship with Valve so don't expect it here neither.There is no way to not recommend it good old times of horror that still lives here to be experienced for a ridiculous low price.EA is in the game? Nope.Just push the discharge button and make it flow within the sewer system. Every game EA puts her greedy hands on, they manage destroy it somehow. Friend, you don't need Dead Space 3. It's just some cool action game that failed to deliver the basics of survival... unless you like some loose gunner game rap*ng your fan love, forget it. Maybe mister Alister is right after all? DS3 is mainly a co-op game but If you're playing alone you will laugh at the character teleport on animation sequences. I won't ever recommend you DS3, it is simply a f*ck*ng joke with a very nice design.

content:
7, 2016
												Do you like space?  Do you like zombies?  Do you like fighting through wave after wave of faceless, terrifying enemies?  If so, this game is a must!Story:  9/10  As Isaac Clark, you get plunged into a desperate struggle for survival as you try to find a way off of the USG Ishimura, a deep-space mining ship that becomes infected with an alien parasite that turns corpses into vicious, mindless zombie things called Necromorphs.  You must fight your way through the ship, repairing key systems and unravelling the mysteries of the ship's mission.  The tory does a great job of keeping the tone of the game consistent throughout.  The whole time, you are seemingly one step behind, as you desperatley try to repair life support systems, engines, etc.  The problem I have with the story is the plot twist at the end, which I won't spoil.  Gameplay:  9/10  This game has one of the most creative combat systems I've come across in my many years of gaming.  It is, at its core, a third-person shooter, but not like the Mass Effect series where you run around guns ablaze.  To kill the necromorph enemies, you have to dismember them with your improvised weapons made from engineering tools.  You have to use your environment to your advantage.  The weapon upgrade system is very simple, yet rewarding.  As the game progresses, the enemies become more challenging to defeat, and require different strategies and weapons to beat.  Also, this game does a great job, in my opinion, of making boss battles.  They are simple and not too challenging (at least at easy difficulties), but I can't think of many modern games with actual boss battles.  Pretty much every level ends with one.  You also have at your disposal a stasis tool that sets anything it hits, wether it's an enemy or malfuntioning door, into slow-motion.  You also have a kinesis tool that allows you to grab things from afar and throw them.  You will have to use these things in conjunction to solve puzzles.Setting:  9/10  The USG Ishimura gets a little boring after a few levels, as everything kind of looks the same.  That being said, I'm a sucker for scientifically accurate space games.  Upon entering the vaccuum of space, you loose sound for the most part.  There are many places of zero-gravity, where you get to float around in dissorienting fashion.  The ship is creepy and almost archaic-looking, which fits the tone of the game very well.  The game has a few moments of horror, especially at the begining.  You pick up voice and text logs throughout the game, which add depth to the story.  Overall, I really enjoy this game.  It also has some nice replay value as it allows you to keep all of your weapons, with their upgrades, and your suit when you start a new game.  The story is also pretty fun the second time around because of the several plot twists you know about from the first play through.  The best thing about this game is the atmosphere it creates when you play it.  If you aren't playing with all of the lights turned off with sound-cancelling headphones, you aren't playing it right!

content:
, 2014
												***I originally wrote this review on 11-04-2008***Creating a successful horror game is tricky. There needs to be just enough of a blend tension, fear and scare tactics so the game does not fall to mundane generic enemies jumping out at players. Dead Space not only creates the one of the best atmospheres in a horror video game, it’s full of enough puzzles, frights and dilemmas to make even the most jaded 3rd Person Shooter player sit up and take notice. You play as Isaac Clarke, a space engineer, traveling to the USG Ishimura, a “Planet Cracker” which is emitting a distress call. After a tense opening sequence, Isaac boards the ship with his coworkers, Lt. Zach Hammond, security officer, and Kendra Daniels, a computer expert, and soon realizes this is no ordinary distress call as the ship has been overrun by an alien race. Isaac gets separated from his coworkers and must fight his way through the alien monsters to bring the ship back online and find a way off the Ishimura. Gameplay: Dead Space has taken every great piece of third person gameplay in the history of video games and combines it together to deliver an entertaining, enjoyable journey. You navigate Isaac from an over-the-shoulder view. There is no Heads Up Display (HUD) in Dead Space. Your health is indicated by the light meter embedded in the spine of your suit spine. Your ammo is displayed above your weapon when you aim and your stasis meter is also located on the back of your suit. What is stasis? It is a piece of technology that gives you the ability to slow down objects and enemies for puzzle solving and reaction time. You can recharge your stasis by accessing stations located throughout the ship or by finding portable stasis packs. Isaac also has the ability to use Kinesis, which allows him to move heavy objects or acquire objects that are out of reach. Stasis becomes available to Isaac a few minutes into the game, and Kinesis becomes available for use when entering the second chapter and has unlimited use.The game's most unique and striking appeal is operating in zero gravity or a vacuum. When entering a Zero-G zone, Isaac has the ability to jump from one side of the area to another. This opens up an new realm of puzzle solving and is some of the most fun sequences in the game. The enemies in Dead Space are deformed humans that were killed and turned into monsters by a race of alien creatures. There are a dozen or so different styles of enemies that navigate their way through the ships ventilation system, which means you may encounter an enemy at any given time. As many enemies as there are, they all can be taken out with the same technique: begin by shooting off their limbs first. Direct hits to the body will waste ammo, especially during fights with the tougher, more advanced enemies. Some of the more memorable enemies are the epic boss fights that also combine a little Zero-G action. The threats on the ship are sometimes not always enemy related. Dead Space shifts gears twice for a little Han Solo, “Don’t Get Cocky” turret action. So how do you take out all the enemies? With a wide range of weaponry of course. Isaac begins the game with a Cutter, an extremely accurate “laser” that fires a wide beam either horizontally or vertically. There are tons of lockers and chests to explore during the course of the game. Some lockers may contain ammo and others may contain credits, which can be used in Stores. At these Store locations, Isaac can store, ammo and items. Isaac is limited in the number of items he can carry, however the number of items can be increased if he upgrades his suit. Usually near by a store, is a Workbench, where Isaac can upgrade his weapons and gear.There is a lot of backtracking in Dead Space. At the beginning of each chapter, Issac exits a tram which carries passengers from one section of the ship to another, and at the end of each chapter he makes his way back to the same tram to journey to the next section of the ship. Isaac visits some sections of the ship more than once. There are tons of save points throughout Dead Space, probably more than there should be. Even if you don not save, Dead Space autosaves so much that you really do not have to save once through the entire game, unless you want to exit out of Dead Space or turn off your PS3. To make the game even easier, the developers also added in a feature that actually maps out the direction Isaac needs to travel to complete his next objective. This feature is displayed by a blue outline on the ground. (see pic below)The problem that most avid gamers will notice is that everything, aside from the zero gravity gameplay, has been borrowed from past films, novels, or other games. The over the shoulder view bares a striking resemblance to Resident Evil 4, the monsters are mere replicas of John Carpenter's The Thing, parallels in Event Horizon are seen throughout the entire game including some obvious set design rip offs and features in Doom 3 and System Shock are also used in Dead Space. It is at this point where we stop and think: are these references by the EA Readwood Game designers an homage to their favs or are they simply thefts? No matter, the similarities are not enough to take away from the Dead Space experience which delivers a terrifying story, but the influences are definitely obvious. Graphics and Sound:Dead Space does everything right graphically. It looks beautiful in full 1080p when staring out into the vast ocean of space, blowing an enemies head off, or playing through some beautiful level designs of what a 'Planet Cracker's' engine room, maintenance bay and mining section may look like. The sound effects are also top notch in Dead Space. As Isaac communicates with his team, a 2D holograph image appears before Isaac, which the player can rotate. The static overlaid onto the video and audio logs is incorporated nicely, and the creeks and cracks heard throughout the broken ship add much to the atmosphere. Listen for the lullaby. Players may pick up quickly on how Visceral tries to scare its players. They use the same formula that Hollywood does, during a tense or critical moment in the game they play loud music like the typical brass pieces you hear in most horror movies. More often than not this takes place when a player looks in the direction of an enemy. So this tactic may help a player in certain areas rather than scare him or her. If a player is not paying attention and some random horns start playing, that is a pretty good indication that there was probably a monster that ran past the door that they probably missed. Pros: controls work extremely well on the PS3, terrifying boss battles, graphics and sound are gripping, Cons: : unoriginal enemies, predictable but engaging story, very easy to beat, lots of backtracking Bottom Line: I recommend this game in spite of my criticism of the unoriginality of some of its elements but it is defendable to question why this game has been so highly touted. Some have labeled Dead Space as the ‘Worlds Scariest Game’ and people are shouting from roof tops to “Buy this game immediately!”. The game isn’t perfect, but what is? It has a wonderfully smooth flowing story, a great environment, near perfect controls and graphics that can make a grown man cry. Dead Space is solid game that should be experienced by as many players as possible. There are striking resemblances to a dozen pieces of work, but they are forgivable. Expect a sequel.

												It's like you were dropped off in a horror movie. The fear will consume you. Your heart will pound after being jumped on when you least expect it. That fear will make you into a heartless machine that will anticipate any attack from any corner. You see that dark corner over there? Definitely going to be jumped there, you think to yourself. You think to yourself that you are the master of horror and know what will happen. You play several scenarios in your head of different actions to take when you get to that corner as you walk over with your gun drawn, anticipating a jump. Nothing. Paranoia is a sign of insansity, my friend. You will not escape this world as the same person you were when you entered.

content:
11, 2014
												A terrifyingly good TPS game. Dead Space - I believe - reinvented the genre and showed that there were originals games at the time. I liked both its sequels - yeah, the 3rd part has more action, so what? The story continues, so this was needed so those of you who prefer the scary parts can easily play the first game again.Pros:--- hologram-like ingame menu: your inventory, the map, and even your objectives are projected in front of you--- the concept of dismemberment: forget everything you learned from FPS games - headshots this time will not work, at all--- amazing graphics and equally high-quality audio: my favourites are the zero-g scenes where you hear your breathing more than the surrounding sound--- high replayability due to the unlockable items, difficulty modesCons:--- not much to say here, really, perhaps that the game can be difficult at times, but not because it truly is challenging but because fighting in close-quarters can only be difficult (you cannot really come up with any proper tactics)The sequels only improve upon the experience by expanding upon the story and giving the protagonist a face and voice.

er 5, 2015
Dead Space is a good ride through a pretty scary ship. Packed with jump scares. The monsters are straight out of the 80's movie “The Thing”, with almost an Event Horizon style of design to the ship. There is a nice leveling up system, and there are some interesting weapons. There is even some Zero G action, which was a nice touch. The game does have a frustrating part at the end of chapter 4, but before you rage quit put down your 360 controller and grab your gaming mouse (solves the problem trust me). Dead Space is definitely one to buy on steam sale if you haven’t played it. The game being older runs well on a most systems (not your grandmas Windows 95, but anything from 2012 and up should be fine). The only thing that could have made this better would be some co-op, but it may have killed some of the atmosphere. Turn off the lights, crank up the volume, and get ready. content:
er 14, 2014
												I find it easier to write reviews in a Pro and Con list style, as I find it's a more effective way to get my meaning across, so please bare with me if it's not to your tastes. The Pro's -Good graphics, even with things like AA and other advanced settings off.-Great atmosphere, especially with the music score at its full intensity and also by letting your imagination wander while playing.  -As I just touched upon, the sound design is fantastic, constant bangs, clunks, moans, and rattles give the effect that you are indeed aboard a decaying ship, with monsters moving throughout it. Fleshy bits make an appropriate "squish" when shot, and guns have an appropriate "oomph" to them. -Good variety of enemies, each with their own strengths and weaknesses. For example, Slashers are fast, but have exposed legs, Pregnomorphs are slow, but hard to take down without spilling their "cargo" all over the floor, etc. Other types of enemies have other weaknesses. -The A.I. is pretty good. Enemies will charge you if you turn your back, pop out of vents that are close to you, swarm you all at once rather than one at a time, etc. -The story is good, but it does have its issues, as I will state in the Con's section. -Voice acting is good, none of the actor's sound like they "phoned it in." While the main protagonist Isaac Clarke doesn't talk, he does make grunts, yells, and appropriately heavy breathing noises when necessary. -Environmental design is great, cargo rooms and mechanical stations are open, crew rooms are more enclosed, with tighter corridors, etc. Rooms are in places that make sense (i.e, no engine room on the opposite end of the ship from where the engines are.) -They story is pretty decently lengthed, I've beaten this game several times (mainly on console) and it still takes me around 8 hours or so. I'd imagine it would probably take a newer player around 10-12 hours to beat.-Character design is good, no one is stereotypical, and each character is decently memorable. -I enjoyed the audio and video log collecting, which helped expand on the backstory and helps determine just what happened aboard the  Ishimura  (the name of the ship you board.)-There's a good variety of weapons, each with their own strengths and weaknesses. There's also different suit levels you can get, which work well and look cool at the same time. -You can upgrade your weapons, armor, Statis unit (slows down enemies and objects), and kinesis unit (pick up objects from a distance) using "Power Nodes" you find throughout this ship or bought through the Store aboard the ship. -Each weapon also has an "alt fire" mode to it. The plasma cutter changes from horizontal to vertical shooting (more useful than you might think) the Pulse Rifle fires in a circle, etc. -Anti-gravity areas are cool, but could have been done better. (They are done better in Dead Space 2 and 3.)-There's more positive aspects, but that covers most of the main bits.-The game also likes to mess with you in small ways, areas that were safe most of the game may not be safe anymore, some enemies come out of unexpected areas, the game tenses you up for a scare that doesn't happen (but it's done well, and on purpose.)  The Con's -Aiming is a bit iffy with a mouse and keyboard, turning of V-Sync helps, which you have to do both in the in-game settings and in the .cfg files for it to actually work. However, I'd recommend playing with a controller if possible, if not, you can still play the game quite well with a M/KB. -While I stated earlier that the story was pretty good, it's not without flaws. For the most part you are the secondary protagonists *itch for most of the game, doing something or other for them, sometimes when it's something they could do themselves. Not to say they sit on their butts all game, but still. -This game also follows the horror game trope of magically seperating you from you allies when a situation arises. Granted, it doesn't do it as often as other games and sometimes you even meet up with them. (Who'da thunk it?)-As I said, this game has a cool variety of weapons, but for a more skilled player, they are unnecessary. I can make it through this game with just the Plasma Cutter and the Pulse Rifle as my weapons, not even touching the others. On console, I've even done an entire run through of the game with  only  the Plasma Cutter. -The A.I. is good, but it does have its..... moments. I've seen Necromorphs pop out of vents, only to hop right back in and pop out somewhere farther away from me. I've also seen the A.I. not want to walk through doorways that lead out of the area, but are willing to hop in a vent and pop out of a vent that  is  in that new area, for reasons I assume that involve the games pathfinding. -The game also can get repetitive after a while, not that it's not fun, but some Necromorph encounters do get predictable (mainly entering a new area and Necromorphs almost immediately showing up.) -The game has puzzles (not that I mind), but almost all of them are pretty basic and easy (at least to me) and don't offer much challenge. -Controls are tanky (much like Resident Evil 4), which is fine, but in some areas of the game (mainly anti-grav and space areas) these controls can get semi-annoying and cumbersome. -The game just isn't that scary for me, it's pretty decently thrilling the first time you play it, and its got its tense moments, but I was never crapping my pants in horror or dreading to go in the next room. I am also hard to scare however, while some people are quite the opposite.  Nitpicks and Personal Annoyances  -The amount of settings are decent, but nothing to write home about, and I was disappointed by some options that were missing. -The game isn't very optimized, I can play Dead Space 2 with higher settings than this one and run higher frames, yet I play this game with the same settings and get noticeably lower frames per second. -Another reason to turn V-Sync off (as if there weren't enough already) is that it causes a noticeably annoying "dragging" feel to your mouse, this is especially present in the Main Menu and the Pause Menu. -This isn't an annoyance, but playing this game with headphones is a good idea, it helps you find enemies easier, helps you get more enthralled in the atmosphere, and just makes it an overall better experience. If I had to give this game a number review it would probably be a 9/10. (It'd be higher without the wonky V-Sync and mild control problems.) And finally: TL:DR -MUST PLAY, BUT 2 SPOOKY 4 ME.

												Dead Space is a fun survival horror game that plays from the third-person point of view. The story is fascinating and will keep you engrossed as you walk through the dark corridors of the USG Ishimura, a "planet cracker" starship that sent out a distress signal. The game has an interesting premise that deserves a single playthrough, but the game does have serious technical flaws towards the game's conclusion that has long been reported on the Internet (lockups, Blue Screen Errors, crashes, etc.) There are a few suggested work-arounds, one of which worked for me, but it essentially kills the game's atmosphere and leaves you disgusted towards the developer/publisher since it is a poorly supported console port.

content:
6, 2013
												I'll be honest and admit that I failed to get into this one on the PS3 some years back, mostly on account of the controls being too unweildy.  But on PC and a keyboard this game frigging ROCKS (no, not just rocks: whopping great spinning METEORS, damn you all)!     Like any great horror game, the sound design is the single most effective element, and keeps you on your toes constantly...at least until the last quarter or so of the game, by which time things do become a mite predictable. But apart from being a tad overlong for its own good, this is pretty well a must-play for anyone who loves the Silent Hill and/or Resident Evil franchises, or similar third person horror games. It's by and largely a remake of Resident Evil 4 set in space, but fresh enough for all that.     Story and setting-wise, its influences are more noticeably cinematic, namely 2001: A Space Odyssey meets Alien, by way of John Carpenter's The Thing. All exceptionally good company, in other words!  Spooky, fun, stupidly violent...all the things any sane person demands in a video game. Looking forward to the next two!!!Verdict: 9.5/10.

content:
er 2, 2015
												When it was released in 2007 I remember Dead Space being one of the best horror games I had played since the Silent Hill 2/Fatal Frame CB-era. Going back how does it hold up today? A bit on the good, a bit on the bad it seems.First off know that if you like horror games and have never picked up the series then there’s really no reason not to play the game. Despite some of its shortcomings it’s still a deeply immersive experience. Though I think the series as a whole gets lauded as “thah scuriest games evurh!” far too often (as you’ll eventually become used to its brand of trying to scare you and begin predicting where the next enemy is coming from) that doesn’t change the fact that the environments are excellently crafted, deeply foreboding, and the gameplay is fun if not perfect. In fact while I believe the later games certainly improved on the mechanics, and I eventually grew to like Isaacs voice (he’s silent in this one), I think overall this game creates a far better atmosphere. You rarely if ever feel safe, the graphics while aged still look nice, and unlike the later entries unless you’re playing on the easiest difficulty or two (or are a horror god) you’ll be rationing supplies to an extent. Additionally while some dislike it I quite liked the fact that except for a few rare occasions almost all communication with others is done via radio, true it isn’t as cinematic as later entries, but it gives the distinct impression that only you can save yourself and no help is coming. It’s true that thanks to an upgrade system most people do feel rather powerful by the end, but you have to work toward that and in the early to middle game it’s true survival horror.As for the bad, well as I said later games improved on the mechanics and that’s because some of the mechanics are broken. The big mechanic of “shoot the limbs” is completely missed by the inclusion of weapons that can do just as much damage shooting for the core (it can be fun to play through with only the base weapon and it is perfectly effective, but isn’t required and if you’re just breezing through can totally be skipped). The Zero-G sections are awe inspiringly painful to play, you’ll get the hang of it but because you have no control and can only jump from point-to-point it isn’t fun. And the physics are all over the place as well as the hit-boxes at times, especially where stomping or some of the more concentrated weapons are concerned.There’s also a small factor that never really bothered me but I see brought up all the time so it’s worth mentioning. This game truly is “fetch quest, the FPS”. Though the underlying plotline, the history, and the environment of the ship itself are all very interesting the actual activities you’re asked to complete aren’t. EVERYTHING is broken and because the other survivors are a bunch of sissy pants you literally get to fix a starship as a one-man engineering crew. The fact that the other elements are so strong glossed over this for me, but lots of people note it and I can’t deny its truth.In short the game is still a classic. Some of it hasn’t aged as well as other parts but like great horror games from the very start of gaming chances are you’ll easily forgive those things in light of the overwhelming positives.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
21, 2014
												Just finished Dead Space on Medium (Normal) difficulty. So far the title has been an absolute thrill, with tension and terror at every turn, some physical and some psychological. The backstory of the game is very deep, with you being able to control the character Isaac in an attempt to escape a ship  filled with the undead alive, preferably with his allies and his wife, who is lost onboard. The background is explored through lost recordings, some video, audio, and text, as well as the environment itself.The title itself is very unsettling, as even bumping into a beer can will startle you. Undead can appear behind you, in front of you, above you, all around you. It was fairly challenging on medium, with an option for Easy, Hard, and an unlockable Impossible mode, which I haven't tried out yet. Items can be found through schematics, bought in the store, and then upgraded through the use of nodes (items which you insert into others to make them better). The story is long, around 8-10 hours if you spend time collecting everything. The replayability factor is large enough for maybe 1 or 2 extra playthroughs, which can be spent using your fully upgraded arsenal, or upgrading it to that, and collecting logs you may have missed.The downsides to this title are mentionable, although they don't detract from the experience very much. No steam achievements, cards, or DLC for this title. I cling to hope that EA may port their dlc to the pc, preferably in a package, although its small. I encountered a glitch, which I read is very common for pc gamers. That glitch is called the "Continue glitch", where if you start the game on any difficulty other than medium, save, exit, then click continue instead of load game, it will change your save to medium difficulty with no way to go back. I started on Easy the first play through, and it happened to me on chapter 2. This can be avoided though, although it hasn't been patched out yet. The aim is also sort of slow, but I can't tell if its a bug or if its part of the games' unique aiming itself.All in all I rate this game a 9/10. Its a great game to start off a series but it is hindered by an almost unavoidable bug, no steam extras, and no pc DLC, although the other two versions of this game recieved it. Get it on discount and you won't regret it.http://www.isthereanydeal.com

content:
4, 2015
												Fun as hell, and possibly the best in the series.  An excellent third person shooter - although not particularly scary.  It's very immersive, and you grow to care about the characters.  There is just enough mystery in the game to keep you interested in the storyline.  The fact that there are distinctive "chapters" you complete helps you feel a sense of accomplishment while playing - beyond the fact that you’re kicking some freak-monster-zombie ♥♥♥.Ammo is somewhat scarce, which allows for a sense of urgency in the game.  The chapters are varied, and present you with all sorts of different obstacles to overcome.  The upgrade system is simple, but certainly effective.   0n normal, monsters are a little tough, but not much of a challenge.  If you're looking for something more difficult, definitely play on hard.  The only criticism I have is that with my particular graphics card - GTX 770 - some of the character models glitch out and flop all over the place. PERSONALLY I find this hysterical, and am actually happy when it happens, but I could see how for a lot of people this could be frustrating.  Ironically running fraps fixes the issue somehow.  The only part that it really affected me is during a section where a boss fight was supposed to be, the boss never spawned - I just fixed it with fraps for that part of the game and all was good.Do NOT use a mouse with this game, however, because it was poorly ported and there are problems with the mouse sensitivity/acceleration/all sorts of other things, which is known issue.  Controller is certainly best in this situation.

												First of all the mouse sensitivity was all over the place. The camera wouldn't move and when it did it would move really slowly, making the game pretty much unplayable. I found a fix for that which still didn't work very well so I decided to play with a 360 controller. That worked fine but then I got to a door which I couldn't walk through because there was an invisible wall in the way. Apparently the first enemy in the game is supposed to come through it and start attacking you but that never happened. It seems a few other people have had this problem because I was able to find a fix which requires you to record with FRAPS while playing which will make the enemy appear and the invisible wall to disappear allowing you to progress.I don't know why I should bother playing any longer if I've already had this many problems in the first 5 minutes of the game. Luckily I got it on sale and only wasted a couple of dollars.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
y 22, 2014
												Dead Space remains my all time favourite game. Replayed it over and over on X-Box, love it so much I got it on PC too. In this game you play as an engineer called Issac Clark and is set far far into the future out in Space. It definately does not lack a horror element and has a very very very good storyline. Play this game with headphones and you will appreciate Viscerals attention to sound details. Metal clashing, electricity buzzing, necromorphs (The monsters) moving around in vents, Issac's breathing, screams - all out horror noises. The graphics are good. Most of the game is quite dim to create the horror element. LIghts and sparks of electricity add to an array of lighting effects.You have a great choice of weapons which can be upgraded in-game by collecting powernodes. I love how you have in-game currency and literally do not have to spend real life money at all.PLAY IT before Dead Sppace 2 & 3 - otherwise the story won't make much sense, plus it's by far the best in the trilology.Dead Space - ruining my life since 2008

content:

												There are few bad things I can say about this game. It has unskippable cutscenes and dialog. Some of the weapons just ain't great. That's about all. What's left is a thrilling experience and engaging gameplay.You will be fighting corpses twisted by a mysterious plague on a mining ship orbiting an alien world. You will not be a soldier though. You will be a space handyman. Against all expectations, you will be the only hope against this inhuman evil and your weapons will be your tools for the most part.Really I want to leave it at that so you can discover the horrors as Issac, the player character, does.IMPORTANT NOTE: I didn't play this for the longest time because the mouse is super laggy without some tweaks. I'm talking a good second to acknowledge my movements. It is fixable. Search google. It's something to do with the V-Sync implementation. You can override it through your video drivers.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 25, 2016
												I really feel like this game must be played on hard difficulty because medium just feels like a casual third person shooter, you get tons of ammo and the necromorphs are easy to kill. Hard genuinely feels like a survival horror game. The monsters feel like a real threat because they are challenging and you have to conserve your ammo which creates alot of tension during the fights. I don't think the game is scary at all however. The atmosphere and setting is great but the scares themselves i didn't find effective at all.I can think of two reasons why the scares don't work, guns and third person. When an enemy jumps out you have a way of defending yourself by shooting them so that vulnerability factor is lessened because of that. This is why games like amnesia and outlast work so well at being scary because you have no way of defending yourself. Even a game like Fear works so well, even though its a first person shooter the scares are supernatural and unkillable which is what makes it so effective. Because the game is in third person the monsters don't jump out in your face like they would in first person. The scares are at a distance from you because you are positioned behind the character you are playing. I don't think the game needs to be scary to work though it's still a great game because of its amazing atmosphere and sound effects and the game is just fun to play. 8/10 (Great)

content:
25, 2015
												Being a huge fan of the horror genre, I was excited to finally get the chance to play "Dead Space" when I did.  The atmosphere and story that this game delivers is just that:  Horror.  The player experiences a sense of dread with every sound, or when rounding a corner.  The developers have said they were influenced by several different horror movies, but the two that shine through most notably are "Event Horizon" and John Carpenter's adaptation of "The Thing".  The story itself revolves around a planetcracker mining vessel known as the USG Ishimura, that sends out a distress signal from the planet Aegis VII.  You play as the engineer, Isaac Clarke, who is dispatched with a small crew to investigate the aforementioned distress signal.  While there isn't much variation on the types of enemies you'll encounter, the game itself is still an enjoyable experience if you love horror.

content:
er 18, 2016
												So as of late I've been pretty bored with games. I've played Mass Effect and found that fun, have been mulling around on Ori  and the Blind Forrest, and have even bought and dowloaded other games that just don't seem to hold my attention. Well, I got some news for you, because I literally have played this game over a four day period from start to finish and loved every minute of it. Dead Space brought horror and dread back into my gaming library like no other game has in a long time. I'm not one for horror games, but if you enjoy sci-fi/action/horror and games like Mass Effect I HIGHLY reccomened you try this game! Pros:- Great use of multiple weapons and different functions for each weapon- Unique grotesque monsters designed off of actual dead and multilated corpses for extra dramatic effect- Enemies are difficult to kill in the sense that they have their own mechanics as in how to kill them all (cutting off limbs etc)- The character Issac may be a silent hero, but certainly a badass for going through some f@$ked up sh#t. - Unique Horror and jump scares- Sound design is wonderful, and you'll learn to hate violin after this game. (Lol)- Good use of starvation on items in certain sections of the game to make you feel like you're at impossible odds until you win.Cons:- Controls are odd and clunky at first, and melee animations and usage is nearly pointless and difficult to actually use- A maze like game where scenery stays stagnent for most of the game and can be boring at times when you enter a room designed like previous ones to know what lies ahead (obviously some baddies from a vent or from a wall)- The game can be very easily manipulated by the player after understanding all monster mechanics, and cheese strating enemies by knowing they cannot enter certain rooms or hallways. (By this I mean using a hallway with a door to protect you, running up so the door opens and popping shots to kill some baddies, then backing away from the door to stay shielded in your safe room)- Ammo clutter for weapons you didn't purchase because the only two weapons you'll ever need is the assult rifle and the pizza cutter (If you play the game, you'll undertsand why i call it the pizza cutter lol.)- underwhelming mini bosses and boss fights using the same mechanics as mobs, or using the same enemy as a boss multiple times.All in all, Dead Space was awesome and I thouroughly enjoyed it! It has its ups and downs with boss battles or mechanics when in Zero gravity and more. But over all it was a fun theatrical experience with many scares. I had blood rushing through my body most of the game. It is loaded with creepy errie sounds coming from vents, objects in the world, dead boddies, and whispers and cries coming from the distance. I can't wait to start playing Dead Space 2! And that's exactly what I intend to do after giving my thoughts on the first one. :)

content:
er 13, 2016
												This is how action/horror should be done- SLOW BURN. I've played this game twice on both 360 and PS3 and now PC. Still a blast. +Simple but engrossing story with a small cast of memorable characters and great voice acting+Even after 5+ play throughs, its extremely satisfying dismembering enemies. Just the crunching sounds alone are fantastic...you can even stomp and crush their bones which is awesome+Lots of scary moments+It IS linear but theres plenty of freedom to go where you want and if you *do* get lost you can simply tap the RS stick and it'll show you where to go+Silent protagonist is always welcome +Nice variety of weapons with a simple but satisfying upgrade system+I like how the inventory, store, and upgrade station are in real time to keep you in the game and the tension high+No stupid silly "epic" moments like so many modern games do today (and back in 2008 too)+Even in almost 2017 the game still looks great and runs @ 60fps 1080p+Includes New Game+ to play on harder difficulties with all your equipment. -Seems like if i exit the game and come back to it, my graphics settings were bumped down to medium. Had to manually do this a few times.  -No achievements like the console versions (a very small minor gripe though)And one of the best things- if you beat this game and loved it like i did and wonder if Dead Space 2 is any good well...let me just say it does *everything* right. Reminded me how Resident Evil 2 improved so much from the first game. This is like that. :)9/10

content:
9
												Heads up, if you listen to the wanks that are whining about the controls please read this before you miss this game.You are wearing a fork lift because Isaac is an engineer. He uses his suit to do heavy lifting. It is quite heavy itself and slow to move around in. So, you will feel it when you move. It is much heavier than what the security guy and the computer gal wear. You will feel like the suit is heavy (it is), top heavy (that too) and fairly tough. It can function in space for short periods of time, so it is not a pair of coveralls.Also, note that his first weapon (and my favorite) is a plasma cutter. Works great in the environment as intended, and not too bad in the new environment he is facing. I jumped back into the game, on sale(!), and it was like old times. Learn to cut the limbs, figure out how to adjust the blade. READ the command prompts BEFORE you exit them. Help is focused on KB/M so I had to futz around remembering how the controller mapped to the functions.If you use a KB/M ... well you are sort of on your own. Sorry, the game was designed for consoles and game controllers. That is how I played it and that is how I am playing it this time.Save points are little access points mounted on the walls. Learn to look for them early. Think old school console save points, like sitting down in Ico or sleeping in Fallout games.

content:
ber 23, 2016
PROS:+ horror atmosphere+ various enemy types+ weapons & their upgrades+ save & inventory systems+ level design+ epic boss fights+ cool storyCONS:- bad optimization for visuals & controls- jump scares stop being interesting after a while- couple of graphical & AI glitchesComment:First let me get the mundane stuff out of the way. Turn v-sync off, otherwise there are big mouse issues. Also tweak the settings a bit, maybe even an .ini file, to make the game handle as nicely as possible. It is a console port and not a very well optimized one. HOWEVER, once you go through this you can start to enjoy this awesome game. One of the most thrilling games I have played. After the fantastic beginning sequence of the game you start your horrible journey. You are a space engineer and after some stuff happens you are basically alone...in space...with a HUGE bunch of monsters that look like the cast of a body horror movie. And indeed gore, blood and decapitations are a strong part in this game. But the scary part is the anticipation, the fear of what awaits you behind the next corner. The sounds, the corpse-filled rooms, the blood trails. And the damn ventilation jump scares. Although honestly you get really used to these after a while. But there is still enough monster variety to keep it fresh. Also the story is nice, nothing super original, but enjoyable. I like the level design and I have to give praise to the boss battles which I liked a lot. The amosphere is excellent through most of the game. All of this made me play in shorter sessions because I could not handle the stress, but that is something you WANT from a horror game. Recommended!P.S.: the low game time is because I played the game DRM-free before and I just wanted to try and see how it works on Steam

												Back when Dead Space first came out I was really not interested in it. I initially thought it was just a modernized System Shock 2 ripoff. When I play it now I don't really see that. It's actually more Resident Evil 4 in space.You play as Isaac Clark and you're sent with a bunch of engineers to repair this one space ship yadda yadda yadda insert Alien reference here. One thing I should mention about Dead Space is it's a very polished game. The graphics and engine still hold up relatively well, and the lack of heads up display is fairly immersive. The storyline leaves something to be desired but like every game in this genre it has good audio logs.At the very least Dead Space still retains good value for money to this day, and if you enjoyed Resident Evil 4 this will appeal to you greatly.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
8, 2014
												Dead Space provides one of the most interesting stories I have ever heard. A heavily immersive third person horror with a well developed story, as well as unique characters and enemies alike. Weapons and pick-ups are a topic in game that can make your brain think. Health is a vital thing, so you need to think about what med packs you should carry; small, medium, or large. You also must make room for ammo, as you might run out of that in only two rooms! Once you have planned out your inventory space, you can now take in the atmosphere-or not. Incredible sound system and atmosphere has you on edge in every location. When those lights turn out, so do the sounds for a brief moment. Then...BAM! Roar! This kind of encounter brings the chills down your spine like no other! Last but not least, is the story. To be honest, the story was the true reason I kept playing, as every chapter kept getting more and more interesting. If you want a scary game to play loud and proud on a dark and stormy night, this will be a keeper.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
1, 2014
												Dead Space is a rare kind of game and one of the best linear singleplayer games I've ever had the tremendous pleasure to play. It has profoundly affected me as a gamer and has shown to me that you can do a lot with a little and make a game that not only plays good, but looks good. I feel it is a classic no one should go without, even if one is faint of heart.Dead Space has been out for many years and, by now, it has been thoroughly explored by player and developer alike. Even still, its well-balanced gameplay, mixing satisfying weapons handling, unique dismemberment mechanics, and survival elements that pressure the player throughout the game, leave it as one of the most entertaining third person shooters I've ever played. Interesting balancing of the player's enemy-slowing stasis module and object-manipulating kinesis tool make for unusual puzzles and gunplay that's more than just gunplay. Weapon balance, level design, and enemy variety all make for challenging combat scenarios that can vary greatly in execution with every combination of weapons, stasis use, and kinesis use.Graphically, Dead Space is unusually high in quality for its technical fidelity. While the game has relatively low detail models and textures, its good aesthetic direction, breathtaking animations, and clever manipulation of lighting and effects make for a game that will remain visually pleasing for a long time. Voice acting by its cast and atmosphere by its audio team continue to blow me away in sheer quality, even after nearly a dozen playthroughs between console and PC that have solidifed nearly every turn in my memory. Overall, I feel Dead Space has such cinematic and aesthetic quality that some live action movies fall short in comparison.A linear game such as Dead Space would be little but an on-rails third person shooter without a good story and, with all its great aesthetic traits in mind, it does not fail to disappoint. While not immensely groundbreaking, its often psychologically-oriented horror, novel take on otherwise run-of-the-mill space zombies, and interesting backstory woven into audio and text logs make it thoroughly enjoyable.No game is without its failings somewhere and, while I feel Dead Space's are relatively few, this game most certainly has some. While understandable as part of its placement in the horror genre, movement feels unusually clunky at times. Physics oddities and interaction with moving objects can make for some very bizarre moments, ranging from comically confounding and common ragdoll spasms to infrequent, but frustrating random deaths and object disappearances. Puzzles are often simple and blatantly obvious, usually relying overwhelmingly on the threat of death rather than true complexity.Additionally, Dead Space was made for consoles first, PCs second. Many users have run into issues with gamebreaking bugs resultant from their setup or PC-specific options and other port problems - such as control scheme modification being difficult at times - and, as with any console port, be ready for a little bit of work to get it to play nice. I, personally, did not experience many issues, but caution and patience are advised regardless.Modding in Dead Space is essentially non-existent, to my knowledge, as with many other Electronic Arts-backed titles. I feel the lack of support for a modding community is an incredible shame, as its gameplay and atmosphere could have been ripe candidates for talented and amateur modders alike.In the end, if you don't own Dead Space, whether you prefer action or horror, I strongly urge you to change course and pick it up. It is a title that has thoroughly impressed me and, for a time, restored some faith in Electronic Arts. It is a game that spooked me, challenged me, and satisfied me enough to buy it for both Xbox 360 and PC. It is an experience that I honestly believe you would do yourself a disservice not to try. It has earned every little penny I spent on it and thensome, and I will remember it fondly for years to come.

content:
9, 2014
												This game is just straight up, no doubt about, 100% fact, awesome. It's also poop your pants scary. The graphics are very dark and detailed, which fits the game just right. The storyline is gripping, extremely intense, and, well, scary! Did I mention this game is super scary? Anyway, the game manages you to put yourself into the main characters shoes very well, even though Isaac Clarke, the man you play as in the game, does not talk, which something very few games manage to do. The gameplay is very gory, violent, and fun. I'd have to say this is one of my favorite games I played this summer, and I have to say, I don't like a lot of scary games!So in conclusion, Dead Space is just plain awesome, and I look forward to playing Dead Space 2 and 3. If you're looking for a game that is scary, but at the same time, has a great storyline and epic mechanics, then this game is for you.

content:
4, 2016
												Yes, this game has weird mouse controls. Now, with all the negatives out of the way, this is hands down one of the greatest survival horror games out there -- that is, if you play it on Hard or higher (a strange bug causing your game to suddenly switch difficulty from Hard to Normal has however yet not been resolved and never will be). Love atmospheric survival horror but feel like being unable to defend yourself is not fun? Dead Space has you covered -- in layers of blood. Yes, one or two well placed shots to limbs (great system, headshots make no sense here anyway) can disarm (har har) the enemy, but the same pretty much applies to you -- ignore an enemy and say goodbye to half of your medpacks.Yes, this game utilizes jumpscares. A lot. But it also loves to fake them with long build-ups that result in a vent cover simply falling off. Together with DS2, this is THE survival horror series of our time. And yes, DS2 has superior gameplay, but it lacks the Alien-like atmosphere of this one. And DS3 lacks the ability to let your wallet intact (don't bother).Recommended: Do Unitologists like Markers?

												Dead Space – это научно-фантастический хоррор-экшен, который рассказывает историю рядового инженера на космическом корабле Исаака Кларка. Перед нами первоклассный научно-фантастический ужастик, авторы которого умудряются аккуратно играть на нервах на протяжении всего приключения.  В игре присутствуют космические зомби и инопланетные расы.  Враги быстрые, резкие, нападают группами и потому каждый бой увлекает, ибо приходится использовать все доступные средства, помнить об умениях, тактически планировать. Моя оценка 9/10.

content:
er 1, 2015
												Highly recommended if you're willing to put up with a wonky port. Vsync locks the game to 30 fps, but running over 60 fps results in gamebreaking bugs. You might be able to fix that by forcing Vsync in your video card control panel, but I have a 144Hz monitor and it didn't work for me, even when I set my monitor to 60Hz.Also, there is awful negative mouse acceleration that makes playing this game with M+K really difficult. Some people have reported that locking to 60 fps fixes that too, but as with the bugs it didn't work for me. So, I ended up playing this game in "console mode" at 30 fps with a controller. That was actually OK, as good frame pacing and tactfully implemented motion blur make 30 fps totally fine in this game, and the shooting is not awful with a controller since it's relatively short-range and imprecise.Anyway, if you're not familiar with Dead Space, it's a survival-action horror-ish game where you have to dismember your enemies by cutting off their limbs rather than shooting them in the head or the body. The combat is excellent and very weighty and visceral. You have to cut, stomp, and bludgeon your enemies to death with engineering tools rather than shoot them run-and-gun style like in many shooter games. You also get to scavenge for ammo, health packs, and power nodes to help upgrade your armor and ammo. It's got a resource management component, but I didn't find that keeping my ammo well-stocked was all that hard.It takes place on a mining starship where the crew have all been infected with an alien parasite that transforms them into the limb-swinging monsters you have to fight. There's a lot more backstory, of course, but to reveal it would be to spoil the fun of uncovering what happened. You learn about the story from clues in the environment itself, rather it's text notes or messages scrawled in blood on the wall. There aren't too many jumpscares - the game is more gory than scary. The level design is linear but gives you just enough freedom to make you feel like you're in a real place and not a corridor. It's clearly dated graphically, but the design aesthetic of the game is consistent and compelling - this is a game world that's fun to look at and explore, even though it's full of gore.Overall, definitely worth a look if you're one of the 2 people who haven't played it yet, but be aware of the PC port issues before buying.

												This game holds up way better than I expected it to. For me it feels like they put Metroid Prime and Resident Evil 4 into a blender and created this beatiful survivor/horror game. As you go on through out the game your skills progress and you find different strategies for how to tackle an enemy. You also can upgrade your suit by buying a new one with credits at the store, and you can upgrade your weapons at benches by spending power nodes which are scattered all over the place. I've been playing the game on hard difficulty, and I'm using mouse and keyboard. It's not that hard of a game, once you figure out the game's core you'll be fine in no time. I would however only recommend this game only to people who don't have a weak stomach. I can't eat or drink while playing, because my body just wants to vommit at some of the grotesque stuff you come across. Enjoy! 9/10

content:
8, 2015
												Haven't gotten around to finishing it yet but, if you like scary games, this is definitely the one for you. While it does have some jump scares, like many games of this type do, it doesn't rely on them in any way, shape, or form. Dead Space is all about ambiance. Almost no matter where you go, there's deep dark shadows where things can lurk, twisted and broken scenery from past struggles, gaps in the walls, ceilings, and floors so that you can see the creatures crawling between walls and into vents. Then there's the sound. At all times there's the sounds of loose metal clanking, echoes of transmissions being broadcast and some of the eeriest music you'll find on a game. All of this combines to engender a feeling of constant anxiety while playing.
